title.narrative: Capacity Building of the SJC in Rwanda, Fojo
Kapacitetsuppbyggnad i skolan för journalistik i Rwanda, Fojo Meia Institute

description.narrative:
Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 Fojo Media Institute submitted a proposal to the embassy of Sweden in Kigali for funding of SEK 17 million to implement a programme "Capacity Building of the School of Journalism and Communication, University of Rwanda" in Rwanda the period 2015-2018.
The programme aims at "On a long-term basis, contribute to building sustainable capacity for the development of an independent, balanced and professional Rwandan media that allow for increased democratic participation among media producers, citizens and other stakeholders". This general objective will be achieved through a specific objective that aims at "Journalism education and training at SJC/GLMC that is more adapted to the needs of professional demands from the media industry as well as the Rwandan audiences’ right to professional, independent and relevant reporting, addressing identified capacity gaps for the increasing opportunities provided by Rwanda’s growing mediainfrastructure and policy reforms." This will be through:1) SJC/GLMC provide high quality education to enrolled students and contribute to the international research field of professional journalism; 2) Students understand media’s social, economic and political role in a democracy and are able to produce professional journalism in a converged media landscape; 3) A strong mutual relationship developed between SJC/GLMC and the media industry, where the two influence each other to jointly professionalise Rwandan media and bridge the gap between academia and practice; and 4) A well-functioning media institute efficiently and effectively delivering services to students and staff.
Fojo Media Institute will implement the programme together with the local School of Journalism and Communication at University of Rwanda.
The programme’s total budget is 17 million SEK, out of which Fojo Media Institute’s own funding is approximately 17 million SEK (2.3 million USD) the total amount contributed by the embassy. The total of ..........million SEK will be forwarded from Fojo to the School of Journalism and Communication.

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Fojo Media Institute har inkommit med ett projektförslag till svenska ambassaden i Kigali för att genomföra ett kapacitetsuppbyggnadsprojekt med School of Journalism (SJC) vid Rwandas statliga universitet, University of Rwanda, under perioden 2015-2019. Stöd kommer också att ges till Great Lakes Media Center (GLMC), som är en enhet under SJC. SJC:s 4-åriga utbildning i journalistik startades 1996. Skolan har cirka 250 studenter och nio lärare. GLMC utbildar verksamma journalister i ett två-årigt program, och håller också kortare kurser på specifika teman. Budgeten för projektet är 17 miljoner kronor.
Projektet syftar till att skapa en journalistutbildning som är anpassad till mediaindustrins behov såväl som rwandiska medborgares rätt till professionell, oberoende och relevant journalistik. För att uppnå detta mål avser Fojo stärka SJC:s och GLMC:s akademiska kompetens och stödja dem att bygga upp ett mastersprogram i journalistik. Läroplaner och kursplaner ska utvecklas, akademisk personal ska utbildas i pedagogik och regionala och internationella nätverk ska stärkas. Dessutom ska utbytet mellan medieindustrin och SJC/GLMC förbättras och utvidgas. Slutligen ska mer effektiva institutionella och administrativa strukturer och rutiner etableras på SJC/GLMC.
Projektet kommer att vara ett av flera svenskstödda insatser i mediasektorn i Rwanda. Sammantaget syftar dessa insatser till att på lång sikt bidra till att bygga kapacitet för utvecklingen av oberoende, balanserade och professionella rwandiska medier som möjliggör ökad demokratisk delaktighet bland medieproducenter, medborgare och andra intressenter.

title.narrative: Capacity Building of the SJC in Rwanda,Fojo

description.narrative: Under outcome 1 (SJC provide high quality education to enrolled students and contribute to the international research field of professional journalism) examples of the results achieved are the following: A curriculum was developed for a Master’s degree in Media and Communication Studies by SJC with facilitation from the Project, awaiting approval by UR Senate and High Education Council A stronger collaboration between SJC and international and national universities was achieved through MoUs (Makerere University, Linnaeus University, University of Nairobi, Wits University) The lecturers research capacity improved - 7 lecturers participated in 6 international research conferences in USA, Ghana, Australia, Spain, Kenya - The number of research papers presented have increased from 2 in 2016/17 to 13 in 2018/19. Students have created their own media houses, examples are Ibishya.net, Ishusho.org. Under outcome 2 (Students understand media’s social, economic and political role in a democracy and are able to produce professional journalism in a converged media landscape) examples of the results achieved are the following: Students have achieved practical radio and TV production skills through enhanced teaching and new technical equipment and strengthened work experience through one-month extra internship. 205 students from year 3-4 were facilitated to do an extra month of extended internship and lecturers were facilitated to go and supervise the students. Under outcome 3 (A strong mutual relationship developed between SJC and the media industry, where the two influence each other to jointly professionalize Rwandan media and bridge the gap between academia and practice) examples of the results achieved are the following: Representatives from the media sector engage in improving the education at SJC. as guest lecturers and speakers from different media houses, agencies and organisations such as: RMC, MHC, Pax Press, ARJ, ARFEM, RBA, New Times, the Chronicles, Taarifa. Those representatives from the media houses also visited the students during internships and participated in the review of the curriculum. Under outcome 4 (a well-functioning media institute efficiently and effectively delivering services to students and staff) examples of the results achieved are the following: Through investments in SJC such as financing a post as a broadcast technician (for one year, the programme support ended 30 June 2020) and improved quality of of computer labs and Media Centre Building students now have improved access to appropriate technical equipment to practice their skills in producing journalism such as radio, TV teaching equipment and software. Students and lecturers also have access to relevant literature on Media and Journalism. The conditions for visually impaired students have improved with support from Fojo. A “Report on support and accessibility for visually impaired students at SJC” has been developed and Braille machines, Braille notepads, tape recorders, headsets delivered and awareness among lecturers concerning lectures and exams has increased. Regarding gender the SJC is gaining knowledge and has itself suggested a new outcome on gender for the cost extension period running till March 2021. Worth noting is that out of five Editors-in-Chief at the Kaminuza Star three have been women. Evaluations show that the Gender Module introduced in the 2016 curriculum is much appreciated as well as the short courses on Gender and Media for professional journalists are valued. The plans for collaboration with the Centre for Gender Studies at Örebro University are a positive step forward.
